exercises.statement: Verify that the row space and nullspace of $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 6 \end{pmatrix}$ are orthogonal complements.
exercises.solution: Row space of $A$: span$\{(1, 2)\}$ (rows are multiples). Nullspace: $x_1 + 2x_2 = 0$, so $N(A) = $ span$\{(-2, 1)\}$. Check: $(1, 2) \cdot (-2, 1) = -2 + 2 = 0$. Orthogonal complements in $\mathbb{R}^2$.

exercises.statement: If $A$ is $3 \times 4$ with rank 2, describe $N(A)$ and $C(A^T)$ geometrically in $\mathbb{R}^4$.
exercises.solution: $C(A^T)$ is a 2-dimensional plane through the origin in $\mathbb{R}^4$. $N(A)$ is also 2-dimensional (since $4 - 2 = 2$) and is the orthogonal complement of this plane in $\mathbb{R}^4$.

exercises.statement: Find the projection of $\mathbf{b} = (3, 4)$ onto the line through $\mathbf{a} = (1, 1)$.
Show that the projection matrix $P = \frac{\mathbf{a}\mathbf{a}^T}{\mathbf{a}^T\mathbf{a}}$ satisfies $P^2 = P$.
Find the least squares solution to $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}\mathbf{x} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$.
exercises.solution: Normal equations: $A^TA\hat{\mathbf{x}} = A^T\mathbf{b}$. $A^TA = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 6 \\ 6 & 14 \end{pmatrix}$, $A^T\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ 11 \end{pmatrix}$. Solve: $\hat{x}_1 = 2/3$, $\hat{x}_2 = 1/2$. Least squares solution: $\hat{\mathbf{x}} = (2/3, 1/2)$.

exercises.statement: Fit a line $y = C + Dt$ to the points $(0, 6)$, $(1, 0)$, $(2, 0)$ using least squares.
exercises.solution: Set up $A\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}$: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} C \\ D \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$. $A^TA = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 3 \\ 3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$, $A^T\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$. Solving: $C = 5$, $D = -3$. Best line: $y = 5 - 3t$.

Gram-Schmidt on columns: $\mathbf{q}_1 = (1, 0)$, $\mathbf{q}_2 = \mathbf{a}_2 - (\mathbf{q}_1 \cdot \mathbf{a}_2)\mathbf{q}_1 = (1, 1) - 1(1, 0) = (0, 1)$. $Q = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = I$. $R = Q^TA = A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.
